item.title:
R to @letsgetonchain: As much as I am excited about EIP 7702 I also have a concern which I already mentioned in the past.
When I onboard my mom under EIP 7702, she will still need an EOA to start of with and hence be familiar with private keys. Cause no matter the smart wallet implementation she upgrades that EOA to, the EOA's private key will always have the ultimate power.. Maybe there is some nice embedded wallet with @privy_io that combines with eip 7702?
Master powers remain though..
Alternatively, is the following flow feasible?
Create EOA -> Upgrade EOA to smart wallet with alternative auth logic -> Delete existence of private key?
Appreciate any input on this 🙏 https://x.com/letsgetonchain/status/1878545580265553927
item.dc:creator: @letsgetonchain
item.description:
As much as I am excited about EIP 7702 I also have a concern which I already mentioned in the past.

When I onboard my mom under EIP 7702, she will still need an EOA to start of with and hence be familiar with private keys. Cause no matter the smart wallet implementation she upgrades that EOA to, the EOA's private key will always have the ultimate power.. Maybe there is some nice embedded wallet with @privy_io that combines with eip 7702?

Master powers remain though..

Alternatively, is the following flow feasible?

Create EOA -> Upgrade EOA to smart wallet with alternative auth logic -> Delete existence of private key?

Appreciate any input on this 🙏
x.com/letsgetonchain/status/…

item.title:
RT by @letsgetonchain: After EIP-7702 and EIP-7212 are live I will recommend my mum to go on chain
Executing any action on chain through touch id is secure and simple.
Can't wait to see it bring unprecedented adoption 🚀
item.dc:creator: @letsgetonchain
item.description:
After EIP-7702 and EIP-7212 are live I will recommend my mum to go on chain

Executing any action on chain through touch id is secure and simple.

Can't wait to see it bring unprecedented adoption 🚀

item.title:
R to @letsgetonchain: Question for such a user onboarding flow.
The first step is still to create an EOA wallet and the first action then is to sign the eip 7702 authorization to a delegated smart contract that verifies Secp256r1 signature.
Thereafter the user can do anything he wants with his touch id, no eoa private key needed.
Do hot wallets even need to store the eoa's private key thereafter or can they just remove it after the user has exported it ?
item.dc:creator: @letsgetonchain
item.description:
Question for such a user onboarding flow.

The first step is still to create an EOA wallet and the first action then is to sign the eip 7702 authorization to a delegated smart contract that verifies Secp256r1 signature.

Thereafter the user can do anything he wants with his touch id, no eoa private key needed.

Do hot wallets even need to store the eoa's private key thereafter or can they just remove it after the user has exported it ?
